verses.text: Lord, do not rebuke me in your anger, nor discipline me in your wrath.
verses.comment: The psalmist appeals to God's mercy, recognizing God's discipline. The use of 'Lord' (YHWH) is significant, expressing covenant relationship. Cross-reference to Psalm 6:1 highlights the theme of penitence, key for Christian (especially Catholic) practice of confession.

verses.text: For your arrows have pierced me, and your hand presses heavily upon me.
verses.comment: The imagery of arrows points to God's judgment and affliction, a recognition of personal sin resulting in divine consequence. Note repentance—central to Catholic teaching—necessary for restoration.

verses.text: There is no soundness in my flesh because of your indignation; there is no health in my bones because of my sin.
verses.comment: Sin affects the whole person—body and spirit. This holistic understanding aligns with both spiritual and sacramental healing (see Catholic anointing of the sick).

verses.text: For my iniquities overwhelm me; like a heavy burden, they are too great for me to bear.
verses.comment: Heavy burden of sin echoes Christ's invitation, 'Come to me, all who labor...' (Matt 11:28). Here we see a foreshadowing of the necessity for a Mediator—fulfilled in Jesus, and sacramentally mediated in Catholic confession.

verses.text: My wounds are foul and festering because of my foolishness.
verses.comment: The personal responsibility of sin (foolishness) is recognized, preparing the way for the doctrine of contrition—a necessary disposition for forgiveness in Catholic teaching.

verses.text: I am bent over and utterly bowed down; I go around mourning all the day long.
verses.comment: Physical posture reflects inward spiritual reality. Sorrow over sin is a classic mark of authentic repentance; Catholic liturgy often incorporates physical expressions of penance.

verses.text: For my sides are filled with burning, and there is no soundness in my flesh.
verses.comment: Physical pain, resulting from spiritual guilt, is emphasized. This can be spiritually interpreted as the soul's agony without God's grace.

verses.text: I am feeble and crushed; I groan because of the anguish of my heart.
verses.comment: The groaning from within is reminiscent of spiritual suffering, echoed by Christ in Gethsemane (Matthew 26:38). This points toward the need for interior healing—achievable by grace, sacramentally administered.

verses.text: Lord, all my longing is before you; my sighing is not hidden from you.
verses.comment: God knows both outward actions and inward desires; Catholic tradition emphasizes prayers of the heart, not only lips.

verses.text: My heart throbs, my strength fails me; even the light of my eyes—it has gone from me.
verses.comment: Loss of strength and vision speaks to spiritual desolation, inviting the reader towards renewal through sacramental grace.

verses.text: My loved ones and friends stand aloof from my affliction; my relatives stay far away.
verses.comment: Alienation from others in suffering. Christ's isolation in His Passion (Mark 14:50) is typified here; Catholics see this as united suffering with Christ.

verses.text: Those who seek my life lay snares; those who seek my harm speak of ruin and plot treachery all day long.
verses.comment: The persecution prefigures Christ’s Passion and those plotting against Him. Link to Matthew 26:4 as foreshadowing fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: But I am like a deaf man, who does not hear; like a mute man, who cannot open his mouth.
verses.comment: Silence under suffering, as in the Suffering Servant (Isaiah 53:7), typologically connects to Christ’s silent endurance before His accusers.

verses.text: I have become like a man who does not hear, and in whose mouth there are no replies.
verses.comment: Stresses patience in suffering, a virtue praised in Catholic spiritual tradition.

verses.text: But for you, Lord, I wait; you will answer, Lord my God.
verses.comment: Faithful waiting upon God is a recurring theme; in Catholic theology, this 'waiting' often takes form through prayer and sacramental life.

verses.text: For I said, 'Let them not rejoice over me, who boast against me when my foot slips.'
verses.comment: Petition for deliverance from enemies mirrors many psalms; this is a call for justice, also emphasized in Catholic social teaching.

verses.text: For I am ready to fall, and my sorrow is ever before me.
verses.comment: Perpetual awareness of sinfulness aligns with the Catholic call to ongoing conversion.

verses.text: I confess my iniquity; I am troubled by my sin.
verses.comment: Confession of sin prepares for forgiveness; direct echo of Catholic sacramental confession. See also 1 John 1:9’s affirmation of confession with forgiveness.

verses.text: But my enemies are vigorous and strong; many are those who hate me wrongfully.
verses.comment: Experience of unjust enemies echoes that of Christ; his sufferings instruct Christians to unite theirs to his, as taught in Catholic sainthood.

verses.text: Those who repay evil for good accuse me because I pursue what is good.
verses.comment: Doing good may result in suffering; Christ’s teaching to love enemies is prefigured here, and is a staple in Catholic spiritual direction.

verses.text: Do not forsake me, Lord; my God, do not be far from me.
verses.comment: Echoes Christ’s cry on the Cross ('My God, My God, why have you forsaken me?', Matthew 27:46). Suffering draws the believer into deeper dependence on God, as emphasized in Catholic teaching on redemptive suffering.

verses.text: Hurry to help me, Lord, my salvation.
verses.comment: Closes with a plea for salvation. In Catholic understanding, salvation is both an event and a process (see Philippians 2:12). The faithful cry to God for deliverance through prayer, sacraments, and ongoing conversion.
